Pipelines failed with a boost shared ptr error coming from yaml cpp:

~~~
In file included from /usr/include/yaml-cpp/node/node.h:16:0,
                 from /usr/include/yaml-cpp/yaml.h:16,
                 from /opt/atlassian/pipelines/agent/build/src/ClientConfig.cc:18:

compilation terminated.

content.raw:
I saw it and I realized that yaml-cpp needs boost. The plan is to remove it entirely in 0.6 but haven't been release yet. We could:

  * Try to compile our own deb with the latest code (I still need to confirm that doesn't use Boost).
  * Install boost.
  * Find a different YAML library.
  * Find a different format for the configuration file.
content.html:
I saw it and I realized that yaml-cpp needs boost. The plan is to remove it entirely in 0.6 but haven't been release yet. We could:

  • Try to compile our own deb with the latest code (I still need to confirm that doesn't use Boost).
  • Install boost.
  • Find a different YAML library.
  • Find a different format for the configuration file.

content.raw: Weird that boost wasn't installed together with `libyaml-cpp`
content.html: Weird that boost wasn't installed together with libyaml-cpp

content.raw:
~~~
$ apt-cache depends libyaml-cpp-dev
libyaml-cpp-dev
  Depends: libyaml-cpp0.5v5

$ apt-cache depends libyaml-cpp0.5v5 
libyaml-cpp0.5v5
  Depends: libc6
  Depends: libgcc1
  Depends: libstdc++6
  Conflicts: <libyaml-cpp0.5>
  Replaces: <libyaml-cpp0.5>
~~~
content.html:
$ apt-cache depends libyaml-cpp-dev
libyaml-cpp-dev
  Depends: libyaml-cpp0.5v5

$ apt-cache depends libyaml-cpp0.5v5 
libyaml-cpp0.5v5
  Depends: libc6
  Depends: libgcc1
  Depends: libstdc++6
  Conflicts: <libyaml-cpp0.5>
  Replaces: <libyaml-cpp0.5>

content.raw: I'm thinking on replacing `libyaml-cpp-dev` with `libyaml-dev`. It's a C API but doesn't depend on Boost.
content.html: I'm thinking on replacing libyaml-cpp-dev with libyaml-dev. It's a C API but doesn't depend on Boost.

content.raw: Do you think it could make sense to pass the path as an argument to `LoadConfig` instead of setting it with a separate call?
content.html: Do you think it could make sense to pass the path as an argument to LoadConfig instead of setting it with a separate call?

content.raw: That was my original approach but I ran into an issue with the default value. The default value is calculated in the `.cc` file and couldn't find a quick way to make it accessible in the header file.
content.html: That was my original approach but I ran into an issue with the default value. The default value is calculated in the .cc file and couldn't find a quick way to make it accessible in the header file.

content.raw: Oh interesting. Thanks for the clarification.
content.html: Oh interesting. Thanks for the clarification.

content.raw: **Update**: `libyaml-cpp-dev` has been replaced with `libyaml-dev`. It's a C API but it doesn't depend on Boost.
content.html: Update: libyaml-cpp-dev has been replaced with libyaml-dev. It's a C API but it doesn't depend on Boost.

content.raw: Missing `...` in the end of the file?
content.html: Missing ... in the end of the file?

content.raw: `...` is not mandatory and I think is only useful if you're sending data over the network. Do you usually see `...`?
content.html: ... is not mandatory and I think is only useful if you're sending data over the network. Do you usually see ...?

content.raw: To be honest, I don't remember seeing the `---` before, but I don't use yaml much. So I looked into it and got the impression that both `---` and `...` [were optional](http://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/YAMLSyntax.html#yaml-basics). I'm fine with the way it is now.
content.html: To be honest, I don't remember seeing the --- before, but I don't use yaml much. So I looked into it and got the impression that both --- and ... were optional. I'm fine with the way it is now.

content.raw: Return here?
content.html: Return here?

content.html: Added in dd59141.

content.html: Should we move on to use the parser if it wasn't properly initialized?

content.html: Modified in dd59141.

content.html: Print an error message?

content.raw: There are several places where we set `res` to false but continue parsing, is it because it's ok to have a partially loaded file?
content.html: There are several places where we set res to false but continue parsing, is it because it's ok to have a partially loaded file?

content.raw: Ok, I see these are more like things that can be ignored and nothing will explode
content.html: Ok, I see these are more like things that can be ignored and nothing will explode

content.raw: Also, `libyaml` needs to use an old-school FILE that needs's to be explicitly closed after using it. If we return directly, we'd have to add a `close()` statement before each return.
content.html: Also, libyaml needs to use an old-school FILE that needs's to be explicitly closed after using it. If we return directly, we'd have to add a close() statement before each return.

content.raw: Not sure where would be the best place to document this, we should remember to write a tutorial in the end.
content.html: Not sure where would be the best place to document this, we should remember to write a tutorial in the end.

content.raw:
That's another thing which would be helpful to document.

What do you think of changing it to something like `IGN_FUEL_CACHE_PATH`, so it isn't confused with the path for the config file?

Also, we may want to print a message alerting that the cache location from the config file will be ignored.
content.html:
That's another thing which would be helpful to document.

What do you think of changing it to something like IGN_FUEL_CACHE_PATH, so it isn't confused with the path for the config file?

Also, we may want to print a message alerting that the cache location from the config file will be ignored.

content.raw: Good idea. dd59141
content.html: Good idea. dd59141

content.raw: tiny suggestion: could `EXPECT_TRUE` here
content.html: tiny suggestion: could EXPECT_TRUE here

content.raw: Thanks, added in dd59141.
content.html: Thanks, added in dd59141.

content.raw: So if a user specifies a custom cache path, the models must be under `<custom path>/models`?
content.html: So if a user specifies a custom cache path, the models must be under <custom path>/models?

content.raw: That's the idea. The user chooses one `root` directory. Then, we'll have one subdirectory for models, worlds, etc.
content.html: That's the idea. The user chooses one root directory. Then, we'll have one subdirectory for models, worlds, etc.

content.raw: I think this is not used
content.html: I think this is not used

content.raw: It's used in `LoadConfig()`.
content.html: It's used in LoadConfig().

content.raw:
There's a problem in the [Jenkins Xenial build](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_fuel-tools-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64/6/console):

~~~
/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/ignition_fuel-tools-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64/ign-fuel-tools/src/ClientConfig.cc:24:41: fatal error: ignition/common/Filesystem.hh: No such file or directory
compilation terminated.
~~~
content.html:
There's a problem in the Jenkins Xenial build:

/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/ignition_fuel-tools-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64/ign-fuel-tools/src/ClientConfig.cc:24:41: fatal error: ignition/common/Filesystem.hh: No such file or directory
compilation terminated.

content.raw:
Jenkins is building common from debs:  `libignition-common-dev is already the newest version (0.4.0-1~xenial).`

Filesystem [is not](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/src/efc1f7567047ac9020c593d6b9e1634b1764f25b/include/ignition/common/?at=ignition-common_0.4.0) on 0.4.0.

I think we either need an ign-common release or to build from source
content.html:
Jenkins is building common from debs: libignition-common-dev is already the newest version (0.4.0-1~xenial).

Filesystem is not on 0.4.0.

I think we either need an ign-common release or to build from source

content.raw: Since this will be a dependency of gz9, I think the release option is safer.
content.html: Since this will be a dependency of gz9, I think the release option is safer.

content.raw: Sounds reasonable.
content.html: Sounds reasonable.
